etymology.type: Pictogram ( 象形 ) or ideogrammic compound ( 會意 / 会意 )
etymology.description: 手(手) (shǒu, "hand") holding a brush (𰀁) -> refers to 筆(筆) (bǐ, "writing brush") -> borrowed for 聿 (yù, "thereupon")
etymology.interpretation: Originally depicting a hand holding a brush, it was associated with the writing brush but later used for its phonetic value unrelated to its initial meaning.

examples.chinese: 文人執聿揮毫(文人執聿揮毫)。
examples.english: The literati wield the brush with masterful strokes.

examples.chinese: 他蘸墨於聿(他蘸墨於聿)，繪出一幅詩卷(繪出一幅詩卷)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zhàn mò yú yù, huì chū yī fú shī juǎn.
examples.english: He dipped ink with the brush and painted a scroll of poetry.

examples.chinese: 古時書生常攜聿遊歷(古時書生常攜聿遊歷)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔshí shūshēng cháng xié yù yóulì.
examples.english: In ancient times, scholars often carried the brush while traveling.
